manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Interactively work with Code Templates. Support for Registers. To insert a Code Template: 1. Invoke "Show Templates ..." action. 2. Select a template from the list. 3. Preview it. 4. Click on Insert to insert the selected Code Template. If the text editor has any selection that wll be inserted at the cursor location resulting after Code Template insertion.. 4. Click Modify... to modify selected template. 5. Click Delete... to delete selected template. To create a Code Template: 1. Select text in editor. 2. Invoke "Create Template..." action. 3. Name the template and insert any parameters using the ${<parameter-name>} syntax. Additional supported parameters: ${selection editable=false} - replaced by the Selection when the code template is inserted. ${clipboard-content editable=false} replaced by the text in clipboard when the code template is inserted. 4. Click on Save to save the Code Template. Cut, Copy and Paste to Registers from 0-9 and A-Z. Xtrl+J R X - Cut to register Xtrl+J R C - Copy to register Xtrl+J R V - Paste from register. Paste is implemented as a template insert so that the magic of parameter substitution can happen. This is implemented using Code Templates named "REG_" + Register name. The "REG_" prefix can be overridden using the System property "org.netbeans.modules.codetemplatetools.REGISTER_PREFIX". It must be string with alphanumerics and _.
manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Module-Dependencies: org.netbeans.modules.editor/3, org.netbeans.modules.editor.codetemplates/1 > 1.1.1, org.netbeans.modules.editor.lib/1 > 1.3, org.openide.dialogs > 6.5.1, org.openide.filesystems > 6.4.22, org.openide.nodes > 6.6.1, org.openide.options, org.openide.text > 6.8.1, org.openide.util, org.openide.windows > 6.4.1

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The GWT4NB project aims to enable developers to take advantage of both: the superior support for creating Web Applications built into the NetBeans IDE and the power of GWT (Google Web Toolkit).
Provided functionality includes: - Using GWT with new or existing Web Projects - Deployment, running and debugging GWT-enabled Web Apps using arbitrary Application Server - Assistance to deal with some code editing nuances such as creating RPC services efficiently
Project Home Page: http://gwt4nb.dev.java.net/

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description:
The NetBeans DTrace GUI plug-in is a Graphical User Interface (GUI) for running DTrace scripts that can be installed into the Sun Studio 12 IDE, NetBeans IDE 5.5, NetBeans IDE 5.5.1, and NetBeans IDE 6.0. You can run D scripts from the GUI, even those that are embedded in shell scripts.

The NetBeans DTrace GUI plug-in is architected in such a way that you can easily extend and customize it.

The GUI package consists of two components: The NetBeans plug-in and the DTraceScripts directory. The DTraceScripts directory contains several subdirectories. Each subdirectory contains several D scripts categorized mostly based on DTrace providers.

For instructions on installing the DTrace GUI plug-in:

  • Click More if you are running the Sun Studio 12 IDE, NetBeans IDE 5.0, 5.1, or 5.5.1.
  • Click the Home Page link if you are running NetBeans IDE 6.0.

NetBeans Dynamic Tracing (DTrace) software includes third-party technologies governed by the third-party license readme at https://netbeans.org/kb/dtracegui_plugin/DTrace_GUI_102007_3rd-party-readme.html.

manifest.OpenIDE-Module-Long-Description: Phobos Debug Interfaces Library. This is a small library module that exposes the Phobos debug APIs to the NetBeans debugger. In order to debug Phobos JavaScripts, a JavaScript editor is needed.
This module defines the EJS (Embedded JavaScript) file mime type. EJS files are the views for a Phobos Application. In NetBeans 5.5.x, the EJS editor is based on the HTML editor.

The Phobos Local Debugger module allows you to debug Phobos JavaScript scripts running on the server side. In order to set breakpoints in a JavaScript file, you need a JavaScript editor (either the open source one for NetBeans 5.5) or the one from NetBeans 6.0.
